articles.headline: Dell Beats Forecasts, Then Surges
articles.snippet: The better-than-expected performance caused Dell’s stock price to surge nearly 7 percent during the final minutes of trading.
articles.abstract: The better-than-expected performance caused Dell’s stock price to surge nearly 7 percent during the final minutes of trading.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Dell feasted on a banquet of corporate technology spending, as large companies spent millions of dollars every three years or so to update their fleets of personal computers. However, ever since the recession began more than a year ago, the computer maker has had to fight for every morsel as companies hoarded their technology dollars.

articles.headline: Afghan Youths Seek a New Life in Europe
articles.snippet: Lone Afghan boys are making their way across Europe, seeking a future that is not possible in their own country.
articles.abstract: Lone Afghan boys are making their way across Europe, seeking a future that is not possible in their own country.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  On the edges of a Salvation Army soup line in Paris, a soft-spoken Afghan boy told the story recently of how he ended up in Europe, alone.

articles.headline: It’s Hard to Worry About a Deficit 10 Years Out
articles.snippet: A decade ago, there was a federal surplus, and taxes were cut. Now there’s a growing deficit. Guess what happens next?
articles.abstract: A decade ago, there was a federal surplus, and taxes were cut. Now there’s a growing deficit. Guess what happens next?
articles.lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, Washington was worried about the budget outlook, and there were forecasts of dire outcomes. And so it is today.

articles.headline: A.I.G. Rises, and Many Ask Why
articles.snippet: “Who would want to buy a stock that’s still 80 percent owned by the government?” wondered William T. Fitzpatrick, an equity analyst at Optique Capital.
articles.abstract: “Who would want to buy a stock that’s still 80 percent owned by the government?” wondered William T. Fitzpatrick, an equity analyst at Optique Capital.
articles.lead_paragraph: It may have been written off as a hopeless case less than a year ago, but the stock of the American International Group shot up to $50 on Thursday, capping a fourfold gain in the last two months.

articles.headline: Construction That Fueled Growth in the Sun Belt Slows
articles.snippet: Areas that tasted the excesses of the housing boom are suffering as the influx of people moving from the Rust Belt has slowed.
articles.abstract: Areas that tasted the excesses of the housing boom are suffering as the influx of people moving from the Rust Belt has slowed.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX  For years, business boomed at Gilberto Preciado’s home-furnishings store in a working-class neighborhood near downtown Phoenix. But on a recent afternoon his showroom was deserted. Other businesses in his strip mall have been shutting down at a brisk clip.

articles.headline: After Iowa Flood, Feeling Just a Bit Ignored
articles.snippet: Recovery efforts in Cedar Rapids have not drawn the attention Hurricane Katrina brought to New Orleans.
articles.abstract: Recovery efforts in Cedar Rapids have not drawn the attention Hurricane Katrina brought to New Orleans.
articles.lead_paragraph: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa  It was more than a year ago that the core of this city was submerged to its rooftops, a result of record flooding on the Cedar River that caused an estimated $6 billion in damage  among the most costly natural disasters since Hurricane Katrina.

articles.headline: Abuse Issue Puts the C.I.A. and Justice Dept. at Odds
articles.snippet: With the appointment of a prosecutor to investigate detainee abuses, tensions between two critical players on the President Obama’s national security team burst into view.
articles.abstract: With the appointment of a prosecutor to investigate detainee abuses, tensions between two critical players on the President Obama’s national security team burst into view.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by Peter Baker, David Johnston and Mark Mazzetti.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, David Johnston and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: For Common Male Problem, Hope Beyond a Pill
articles.snippet: For some, pills like Viagra and Cialis don’t work. And even if they do, there are more cost-effective ways to treat a problem that grows more common with age.
articles.abstract: For some, pills like Viagra and Cialis don’t work. And even if they do, there are more cost-effective ways to treat a problem that grows more common with age.
articles.lead_paragraph: IF you watch enough television, you’d think that treating erectile dysfunction was as effortless as popping a pill and then whirling your partner around the living room in a romantic dance. Correcting erectile dysfunction, alas, is not so simple  and it can be rather costly. One Viagra pill, for example, the most common way to treat erection problems, costs about $15.
